thread.title: Taylor Swift lights up Rogers Centre [Photos]
thread.title_full: Taylor Swift lights up Rogers Centre [Photos]

title: Taylor Swift lights up Rogers Centre [Photos]
text:
TORONTO - 
It’s Taylor Swift’s world - we just live in it. 
The biggest pop star on the planet right now brought as many of 50,000 fans (read: mostly girls and women of all ages) into her not-so-private universe on Friday night at the Rogers Centre as her 1989 World Tour arrived for the first evening of a two-night stand at the stadium. 
“Welcome to the 1989 World Tour,” said Swift, as she opened the two-hour show with Welcome To New York surrounded by dancers, and her band hidden somewhere in the back of her enormous stage. 
Following sustained cheers and applause, and the second song, New Romantics, she elaborated only more slightly. 
“Well good evening Toronto,” she said. “I’m Taylor, there’s absolutely no more beautiful sight than 50,000 of you in this sold out stadium on a Friday night!” 
Swifty’s latest trek is named after her 2014 album of the same name which was recently covered track-by-track by Ryan Adams who said the upbeat energy of the disc got him through his divorce to Mandy Moore. 
She certainly bought a nifty bag of tricks with her - plus surprise guest Keith Urban - from a wristband handed out to every concertgoer that sprang to life in a different colour depending on the song and Swift’s own neo pink polkdot two piece outfit that lit up in the dark during How You Get The Girl as her dancers frollicked in umbrellas under the rain. 
Several costume changes later, Swift also got back to basics to strum her acoustic guitar and sing the old song You Belong With Me just so she could hear the crowd’s roar as it sang along. 
Then it was back to impressing us again with a catwalk that moved her around the audience during Clean and had a keyboard attached to the front of it for a drastic remixing of another oldie but goodie Love Story. 
Other highlights saw her strutting in a silver sequined mini-dress during Style, performing some kicks in a black leather jumpsuit for Bad Blood, strapping on an electric guitar for a rocking version of We Are Never Ever Getting Back Together, and donning a green sequined fringed dress for the show ending Shake It Off which found her and her dancers back on the rotating catwalk with fireworks and confetti exploding as the song came to a close. 
Swift has performed duets with many high profile musical guests on most dates of the 1989 trek - Ed Sheeran, The Weeknd, Lorde, Mary J. Blige, Alanis Morissette, Beck, St. Vincent, Selena Gomez, Justin Timberlake, Avril Lavigne, Steven Tyler and Mick Jagger among them - so guessing who’d she be dragging onto stage every night is half the fun. 
Urban appeared towards the end of the show to perform his latest country hit, John Cougar, John Deere, John 3:16, alongside Swift plus older song, I Wanna Love Somebody Like You. 
Opening were Pickering, Ontario’s own 17-year-old rising pop star Shawn Mendes and Australia’s Vance Joy. 
“What’s up Toronto? I’m happy to be home!” said Mendes, dressed plainly in a black T-shirt and jeans and just accompanying himself on acoustic guitar. 
His first song I Don’t Even Know Your Name didn’t exactly set the place on fire but more than a few people recognized his breakthough song, Life of the Party, and the crowd finally started singing along to Something Big and Stitches. 
Joy was also an acoustic guitar strummer but at least he had a backing band even if his cover of Sam Smith’s Stay With Me fell really flat. 
Live coverage recap
